official-title.#text:
To posthumously award a Congressional gold medal to
		  Shirley Chisholm.

cosponsor.#text: Mr. Danny K. Davis of Illinois
Ms. Eddie Bernice Johnson of Texas
Mrs. Carolyn B. Maloney of New York

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced the
			 following bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text:
Shirley Chisholm Congressional Gold
			 Medal Act

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the
The

Shirley Chisholm
			 was a pioneer: She was the first African-American woman elected to Congress in
			 1968 where she served until 1982.

Shirley Chisholm
			 inspired and led the march of political achievement by African-Americans and
			 women in the three decades since she ran for the Presidency of the United
			 States.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
and her candidacy for the Presidency raised the profile and
			 aspirations of all African-Americans and women in the field of politics.

text.#text: Her election to

Shirley Chisholm
			 was recognized for her activism, independence, and groundbreaking achievements
			 in politics during and after the civil rights era.

Shirley Chisholm
			 was born in Brooklyn, New York, on November 30, 1924, attended Brooklyn
			 College, and earned a Master's degree from Columbia University.

Shirley Chisholm
			 worked in education and social services before being elected to the New York
			 State Assembly in 1964.

Shirley Chisholm
			 established the Unity Democratic Club in 1960, which played a significant role
			 in rallying Black and Hispanic voters in New York City.

In 1969, Shirley
			 Chisholm began her service in the 91st Congress, representing Brooklyn's 12th
			 Congressional District in the United States House of Representatives.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, Shirley Chisholm promoted the employment of
			 women in Congress and was vocal in her support of civil rights, women's rights,
			 and the poor, while fervently opposing the Vietnam War.

text.#text:
During her service
			 in the

In 1972, Shirley
			 Chisholm was the first African-American to seek the nomination of a major party
			 for

Shirley Chisholm
			 was a co-founder of the National Organization for Women.

An historic
			 figure in American political history, Shirley Chisholm died at the age of 80 in
			 Ormond Beach, Florida, on New Year's Day 2005.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, of a gold medal of
			 appropriate design in commemoration of Shirley Chisholm, in recognition of her
			 activism, independence, and groundbreaking achievements in politics, her
			 election as the first African-American woman in the

, and her campaign
